Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Medium: Collaborative Research: On-demand Physical Layer Cooperation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Wireless access is fast becoming the primary portal to the Internet, causing an exponentially rising demand for wireless data. This has pushed current wireless systems to their limits, despite significant investment in infrastructure to meet the ever-growing demands. Physical layer cooperation can enable near-optimal usage of the available wireless bandwidth.

This proposal fundamentally rethinks physical-layer cooperation by introducing an on-demand approach to wireless cooperation. It can be argued that the success of the (wired) Internet was made possible by its on-demand operation, using adaptation, local knowledge, feedback and a best-effort service model. Notably, the success of many peer-to-peer network protocols is closely tied to on-demand information propagation and adaptation of the network. The broad goal of this proposal is to bring this philosophy to wireless networks, enabling near-optimal usage of the wireless network bandwidth within the complexity constraints of implementable systems. This project aims to complement the theoretical work with proof-of-concept deployments on software radio testbeds, and also engage industry partners to impact next-generation wireless network designs. The project also promotes training of research engineers, through a plan to establish a unique inter-university education and research program, which will include joint and collaborative student advising and curricular development.

The underlying assumption of most network information theory works is that one can build architectures which tightly coordinate the estimation and sharing of information about the wireless channels, the user requirements and the network topology, at a very fast time-scale, without impacting the performance (rates, error). That is, the cost of learning the very dynamic network state is not accounted for. Another implicit assumption is complete network usage, that all available relays in a wireless network are used, with no adaptation to user demand. This can be very wasteful in many situations, and again, the cost of unnecessarily using relays is not accounted for. The many breakthrough ideas based on these assumptions have advanced a collective understanding, but bringing physical layer cooperation techniques closer to practical networks requires additional steps to move beyond these assumptions. This project puts together a program that develops the theoretical foundations and practice of an on-demand network operation, that dispenses with these assumptions. This entails operating specific subsets of the network relays (sub-networks) that fulfill target rates, as opposed to using all network relays to achieve the best possible performance. This project constructs a theoretical understanding of how to select, adapt and operate these sub-networks on demand, by using accountable partial network knowledge and using feedback mechanisms to enhance signal adaptation to the unknown. The theoretical formulations are tightly coupled to implementable protocols that will be validated in test beds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project, which started in 2015 was motivated by a simpleobservation that wireless access was fast becoming the primary portalto the Internet, causing an exponentially rising demand for wirelessdata. The challenge was that it was pushing current wireless systemsto their limits. Theoretically, physical-layer cooperative techniquescould significantly enhance wireless data rates. However, the theorywas based around the ability to the build architectures which tightlycoordinate the estimation and sharing of information about thewireless channels, the user requirements and the network topology, ata very fast time-scale, without impacting the performance (rates,error). That is, the cost of learning the very dynamic network stateis not accounted for.  This proposal advocated an on-demand approachto wireless cooperation that could overcome these assumptions.


This project developed several fundamental ideas towards suchon-demand wireless networks and the information theory for it, whichwere discovered and published during the course of this project.  Thedetails are in the publications and were also summarized in annualreports of the project. We would like to highlight the following: (i)Non-coherent (fading) wireless networks: we proved that training basedschemes could be suboptimal when wireless network parameters areunknown, by characterizing its approximate capacity (ii) Harnessingbursty interference: we developed schemes to harness scenarios when wehave intermittent interference and approximately characterized itscapacity (iii) Hierarchical routing for dynamic wireless networks: wedeveloped new routing algorithms for dynamic (mobile) wirelessnetworks by discovering connectivity which varies over time (iv)Redundancy for collaborative optimization: we developed an encodedoptimization framework for learning with lossy communication links.(v) MmWave networks: we developed the 1-2-1 model that captures thedirectivity and beam-steering capability of mmWave networks; over thismodel, we developed efficient methods to calculate the capacity, andpolynomial time algorithms to find the optimal schedule.  (vi) Halfduplex wireless networks: we developed a closed form for the capacityof half duplex paths, as well as efficient schedules for half duplexnetwork relays.  (vii) Wireless network simplification: we exploredwhat fraction of the capacity we can achieve by using a small numberof network relays over a number of configurations. For example, wefound that using a single path (routing) over an arbitrary network canin the worst case achieve O(1/N) of the network capacity, with N thenumber of relays.


One measure of academic impact of the project is the number ofpublications during the duration of the project; this project resultednearly 50 publications (that acknowledged support of this grant) intop tier conference and journals.  It also supported (in part) the PhDwork of four graduate students, two postdoctoral researchers andseveral undergraduate (REU) students. The graduated PhD student andpostdoc have gone on to careers in industrial research labs andacademia. For example, two of the female REU students supported by theproject published journal papers supported by the project and also wonprestigious awards (see annual reports). Another example is a femalepostdoc supported by the project went on to a tenure-track position atthe University of Minnesota. The research in this project alsofostered a collaboration with industrial research labs (Qualcomm andBell labs) through joint publications. The work was also disseminatedthrough several invited lectures in various industrial and academicsettings by the PI, and through organization of workshops andconferences.
